unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Coin Toss Game
question_text: Two friends are playing a game where you toss a fair two-sided coin. When it is your turn, you flip the coin once and record your result. Then, to keep playing you flip the coin until you no longer match your initial flip. Player $A$ flips "tails" $10$ straight times. Player $B$ gets upset and thinks the coin is rigged. Player $A$ states that since it's a random chance device, the side is not pre-determined. Is Player $A$ correct?

choices.text: Yes - But the coin will most likely flip 10 10 "heads" on the next ten flips.
Yes - although improbable, since it's a random chance device, a pattern does not imply the data is not random.
No - 10 10 "Tails" in a row is impossible and the coin is rigged.
No - Since there's only two outcomes, you would be guaranteed 5 5 "heads" and 5 5 "tails" on the 10 10 flips.
No - Because "tails" never fails, therefore since he went first the probability of "tails" is greater.

solution:
A coin is a great example of a chance device as it has two equal outcomes with the same probability . Flipping a coin will result in either a "heads" outcome or a "tails" outcome.

When we examine the data from a chance device, it is important to note that fact that simply because there is a pattern in the data, this does not imply that the data is not random. On each flip, the coin still have an equally likely chance to land on "heads" or "tails", therefore it is theoretically possible to have 10 10 "tails" in a row.

Choice 'B' is correct.
